text: Promised I’d share my Outlook email story in a roundtable today. For those who’re interested I’ll post it in this thread.

I used to build a ton of marketing emails prior to working at HubSpot.

Often a designer would mock up what the email was intended to look like ahead of it going out.

This time the designer had given me an email where the top 75% of the email was basically just a graphic of the product being marketed. There was 1 short line of text, but it was a situation where it was fine to just provide that text as alt text.


The remaining part of the email was just a little blurb about the product, and a link, then all the CAN-SPAM stuff.

Anyhow I’m in a rush. I have a deadline of only 4 hours to build this fresh new design out. (this is before cool tools like MJML and foundation for emails).

I build out this table layout, have a big image up top probably around 1200px tall. Like I said it was big.

Style up all the text etc. things are going fine. Then I start testing. Gmail - perfect, Mac mail - perfect, android email - perfect, then I get to outlook…

That giant image for some reason had a giant gap of space in it, about 300px tall. As if I had split the image in two and just put white space. Horrified, I start googling around trying to figure out what in the world could cause such a thing.

I spent about 2.5 of my 4 hours just sweating trying to figure out how to fix this weird issue.

I come across 1 lone thread on the internet, about how somoene tried sending an image attachment through outlook and the same thing happened. That dreaded moment everyone has - no solution discovered.

Then I remember, that version of outlook is using Microsoft Word as it’s rendering engine. My brain starts ticking - what applies to Microsoft Word, but doesn’t make sense to an email?




Think about what happens if you add an image to a page in Microsoft Word that is too large for the page…

…





It splits the image onto a separate page.

_My EMAIL was being split across “pages”, because it was too tall to fit on an 8.5 by 11in sheet of paper._

The solution - doing the very thing Microsoft was doing, split the image into two separate images, place them ontop of eachother. This stopped the goofy gap.

So that’s my goofy Outlook story.
